div.p: Spinel type nitrides formed by the group 14 elements, namely Si 3 N 4 , Ge 3 N 4 and Sn 3 N 4 , offer a new class of compounds with potentially useful mechanical and optoelectronic properties [1][2][3][4][5][6]. This project aims to investigate the formation and stability of a novel (Ge 1-x Sn x ) 3 N 4 in the spinel structure (called γ-phase) at high pressures and high temperatures (HP-HT). In the first efforts, we studied the HP-HP behavior of γ-Sn 3 N 4 and 1:1 mixture of γ-Sn 3 N 4 and  -Ge 3 N 4 (Sigma-Aldrich). The starting materials, spinel-Sn 3 N 4 was synthesized [7] by ammonolysis of Sn(NMe 2 ) 4 complex at TU Darmstadt (Prof. Ralf Riedel group). At the ID06-LVP beamline, we performed following experiments.

div.head: Starting material
div.p: During in situ investigations, Spinel type tin nitrides under above mentioned P-T conditions (Exp1,2 and 5) show a few new unknown reflections (Figure 1). Unfortunately, we were unable refine the structure or identify the chemical composition. Recovered samples appear altered with a yellow (with reddish tinge), and results from the Exp4, 1:1 mixture of tin and germanium nitride experiment also appear inconclusive. When we tested these mixtures using the six ram large volume press (LVP) installed at DESY beamline P61.2, we obtained the mixture of γ-Ge 3 N 4 and γ-Sn 3 N 4 (Figure 2) without additional unknown reflections seen at ID06 . Therefore, we were unable to reproduce our in situ experiment results and in both cases no solid solution could be obtained. These outcomes can be attributed to mainly the following, a) reaction of sample with surrounding materials when no metal capsule is used (for X-ray transparency), b) starting materials contained considerable amount of oxygen (based on later analysis).

During beamtime, we carried out an experiment on one additional sample namely, chromium telluride CrTe 3 . Chromium tellurides reveal a large variety of structural, electrical and magnetic properties and became increasingly attraction since the discovery of ferromagnetism in CrTe [8]. Most chromium tellurides are metals and have a transition into the ferromagnetic state at higher temperatures [9]. High-pressure hightemperature (high-PT) in situ synchrotron X-ray diffraction experiments were performed to study the high-PT stability of the CrTe 3 compound at the ID06-LVP beamline at ESRF. High-PT in situ investigations reveal a temperature-induced phase transformation of CrTe 3 from the monoclinic to the orthorhombic crystal structure at pressure of 10.5 GPa and temperature of 230°C. The monoclinic structure remains stable during pressurization up to 10.5 GPa. The phase transformation can be clearly identified in the 2D diffraction patterns in Figure 3. The monoclinic CrTe 3 reflection (023; 22-3) around 4.6° 2Θ diminish, while two new reflections occur at 4.5° and 4.8° 2Θ. This result is promising for further investigations.
